@rita_rdevlin29 tells @BBCgmu that @RCN_NI members will find it very disappointing that car parking charges are to be reinstated for staff and patients today. There are no charges in Scotland and Wales.

Further to today's @NIAuditOffice report, @RCN_NI told @niahealth in April 2015: "Workforce planning for nursing must address, in particular, the needs of the nursing home sector and GP practices, as well as those of our hospitals, health centres and community services."

@SDLP MLA Mark H Durkan: "It is important to remember that pre-Covid, the nurses‚Äô strike was not just about pay but rather safe staffing. This is a pre-existing problem, brought about by years of failures with workforce planning under previous Executives."
https://t.co/ybeX2FPX7S
@NIAuditOffice This is an excellent summary of the many important issues highlighted in the @NIAuditOffice report.

@sinnfeinireland health spokesperson @GildernewColm on today's @NIAuditOffice report: "The Minister for Health needs to progress the recommendations and work with staff and trade unions to address workforce concerns, including safe staffing levels." https://t.co/1Kufq7qXEi https://t.co/HCzaXZ2Gdh

"For far too long, workforce planning for nursing has been driven by short-term financial considerations resulting in nursing posts and pre-registration nursing student places being cut. Work on safe nurse staffing legislation must begin now."@patcullen9  https://t.co/oi9YL20wbS

6/6 "Nurses have rightly been recognised for their unprecedented contribution during this pandemic. Now is the time to ensure that this translates into action. That includes ensuring we have the right numbers of nurses in the right places and that nurses are properly rewarded."

5/6 "Work on safe nurse staffing legislation must begin now. We are also concerned that, in the @theRCN‚Äôs latest employment survey, it was revealed that 36% of nursing staff were considering leaving the profession due to poor staffing, poor pay and how they have been treated."

4/6 "We recognise the safe staffing framework published by the Health Minister will begin to address many of the problems highlighted by the NIAO. However, we also know it may take several years before we see the outcome of these changes and achieve a more stable workforce."

3/6 "The short-term decisions that were taken have created a much larger problem that will take longer to resolve. This is one of the reasons why it is so important that we have safe nurse staffing legislation implemented in Northern Ireland as soon as possible."

2/6 "For far too long, workforce planning has been driven by short-term financial considerations, resulting in nursing posts and pre-registration nursing student places being cut. This has resulted in using expensive temporary staff from internal banks and external agencies."

1/6 Commenting on today's @NIAuditOffice report on workforce planning for nursing and midwifery, @RCN_NI Director @patcullen9 said: "This important report illustrates clearly issues the RCN has been raising on behalf of nurses in Northern Ireland for years."
